It's her thing about half-breeds all over again — she's trying to make out Hagrid's some kind of dim-witted troll, just because he had a giantess for a mother —</i>"</span></dd>
<dd>— Hermione expressing her hatred of Umbridge, over Umbridge's persecution of Hagrid<sup class="noprint"><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Order_of_the_Phoenix" title="Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix">[src]</a></sup></dd>
<dd></dd></dl></div>
<figure class="thumb mw-halign-left show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 200px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/4/4e/Dolores_Umbridge_DHF1_promotional_image.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20101127041001" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Dolores Umbridge DHF1 promotional image" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="200" height="264" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Dolores Umbridge DHF1 promotional image.jpg" data-image-key="Dolores_Umbridge_DHF1_promotional_image.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/4/4e/Dolores_Umbridge_DHF1_promotional_image.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20101127041001" /></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/4/4e/Dolores_Umbridge_DHF1_promotional_image.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20101127041001" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Dolores Umbridge DHF1 promotional image" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/4/4e/Dolores_Umbridge_DHF1_promotional_image.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20101127041001" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="200" height="264" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Dolores Umbridge DHF1 promotional image.jpg" data-image-key="Dolores_Umbridge_DHF1_promotional_image.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/4/4e/Dolores_Umbridge_DHF1_promotional_image.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20101127041001" /></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			<a href="/wiki/File:Dolores_Umbridge_DHF1_promotional_image.jpg" class="info-icon"><svg><use xlink:href="#wds-icons-info-small"></use></svg></a> 		 		 		 			<p class="caption"><a href="/wiki/Dolores_Umbridge" title="Dolores Umbridge">Dolores Umbridge</a>, her former professor and enemy</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Dolores Umbridge was appointed <a href="/wiki/Defence_Against_the_Dark_Arts" title="Defence Against the Dark Arts">Defence Against the Dark Arts</a> professor by the <a href="/wiki/British_Ministry_of_Magic" title="British Ministry of Magic">Ministry of Magic</a>, in <a href="/wiki/1995" title="1995">1995</a>. She was a sadistic woman who enjoyed punishing and torturing students using the <a href="/wiki/Black_Quill" title="Black Quill">Black Quill</a>, most notably when she forced <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter" title="Harry Potter">Harry Potter</a> to carve <i>'I must not tell lies</i>' into the back of his own hand. Umbridge was as obsessed with blood-status as the <a href="/wiki/Death_Eaters" title="Death Eaters">Death Eaters</a>, and had a particular hatred of what she called '<i>half-breeds</i>.' Hermione, like most of the students and staff at Hogwarts, hated Umbridge. Hermione was one of the first to pick up on the true motives behind Umbridge's appointment at the magical school. In turn, Umbridge was not too fond of Hermione, who was not only <a href="/wiki/Muggle-born" title="Muggle-born">Muggle-born</a>, but was also probably far too perceptive for her liking, as well as being outspokenly opposed to a purely theoretical <a href="/wiki/Defence_Against_the_Dark_Arts" title="Defence Against the Dark Arts">defensive</a> magical education. Despite this, Umbridge could not help but be impressed, however reluctantly, when Hermione effortlessly quoted a phrase from <i><a href="/wiki/Defensive_Magical_Theory" title="Defensive Magical Theory">Defensive Magical Theory</a></i>. 
</p><p>When Umbridge planned to use <a href="/wiki/Veritaserum" title="Veritaserum">Veritaserum</a> and then the <a href="/wiki/Cruciatus_Curse" title="Cruciatus Curse">Cruciatus Curse</a> on Harry, Hermione was the one who came up with the lie that led to them venturing into the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_Forest" title="Forbidden Forest">Forbidden Forest</a> and Umbridge eventually being dragged away by a <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_Forest_Centaur_colony" class="mw-redirect" title="Forbidden Forest Centaur colony">herd of offended centaurs</a>.
</p><p>Hermione next met Umbridge a second time at the Ministry of Magic in 1997, when Hermione was disguised as <a href="/wiki/Mafalda_Hopkirk" title="Mafalda Hopkirk">Mafalda Hopkirk</a> through the usage of <a href="/wiki/Polyjuice_Potion" title="Polyjuice Potion">Polyjuice Potion</a>. Umbridge was, at the time, interrogating 'Mudblood' witches and wizards, prior to sending them to <a href="/wiki/Azkaban" title="Azkaban">Azkaban</a>. Harry stunned Umbridge and retrieved <a href="/wiki/Slytherin%27s_Locket" title="Slytherin's Locket">Salazar Slytherin's Locket</a>, one of Voldemort's Horcruxes which Umbridge had taken from <a href="/wiki/Mundungus_Fletcher" title="Mundungus Fletcher">Mundungus Fletcher</a> and was attempting to pass off as a family heirloom and proof of her relation to the <a href="/wiki/Selwyn_family" title="Selwyn family">Selwyn family</a>. Hermione replaced the locket by duplicating it with the Geminio spell so Umbridge would not know that it had been taken from her. The trio proceeded to free all the Muggle-Borns awaiting interrogation.
</p><p>Suffice it to say that Umbridge personified everything that Hermione detested and loathed in Wizarding society, including but not limited to racial prejudice, sadism, malicious misuse of power, authoritarianism, and pure-blood supremacy.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Septima_Vector">Septima Vector</span></h4>
<figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 200px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/6/6d/Professor_Vector_PSF.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20230218145508" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Professor Vector PSF" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="200" height="296" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Professor Vector PSF.jpg" data-image-key="Professor_Vector_PSF.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/6/6d/Professor_Vector_PSF.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20230218145508" /></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/6/6d/Professor_Vector_PSF.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20230218145508" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Professor Vector PSF" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/6/6d/Professor_Vector_PSF.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20230218145508" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="200" height="296" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Professor Vector PSF.jpg" data-image-key="Professor_Vector_PSF.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/6/6d/Professor_Vector_PSF.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20230218145508" /></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			<a href="/wiki/File:Professor_Vector_PSF.jpg" class="info-icon"><svg><use xlink:href="#wds-icons-info-small"></use></svg></a> 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Septima Vector, her Arithmancy professor</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<div class="quote">
<dl><dd><span title="Source: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">"<i>I heard her talking to Professor Vector, that Arithmancy witch, this morning. They were going on about yesterday's lesson...</i>"</span></dd>
<dd>— Ron Weasley having witnessed Hermione talking to Professor Vector<sup class="noprint"><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">[src]</a></sup></dd>
<dd></dd></dl></div>
<p>Hermione also had a good relationship with her <a href="/wiki/Arithmancy" title="Arithmancy">Arithmancy</a> <a href="/wiki/Septima_Vector" title="Septima Vector">Professor Septima Vector</a>. Many students disliked Vector because of her strictness. However, Hermione said Arithmancy was her favourite subject at <a href="/wiki/Hogwarts_School_of_Witchcraft_and_Wizardry" title="Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry">Hogwarts</a>. She also never complained about Vector's strictness. During her <a href="/wiki/Third_year" title="Third year">third year</a>, Hermione joined her class and used a <a href="/wiki/Time-turner" class="mw-redirect" title="Time-turner">time-turner</a> to get to one of the lessons.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Then in her <a href="/wiki/Fourth_year" title="Fourth year">fourth year</a>, Hermione and the other students got no homework from Septima Vector on the first day of term,<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and she adamantly refused to skive Arithmancy.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_58-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>Rowling took Hermione's name from William Shakespeare's <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Winter%27s_Tale" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:The Winter's Tale">The Winter's Tale</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-TNPC1999_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TNPC1999-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> saying that she wanted it to be unusual, since if fewer girls shared her name, fewer girls would get teased for it.<sup id="cite_ref-TNPC1999_79-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TNPC1999-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Rowling's knowledge and interest in Greek mythology may have also influenced her choice in regards to Hermione's name. In 1988, Rowling wrote a short essay about her time studying classics entitled '<i>What was the Name of that Nymph Again? or Greek and Roman Studies Recalled</i>'; it was published by the University of Exeter's journal <i>Pegasus</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The name 'Hermione' is derived from 'Hermes', who was the messenger of the Greek gods, as well as the god of wit, eloquence and quick thinking.
</p><p>'Hermione' is the female derivative of 'Hermes', a messenger god known for his sharp wit and ability to transition between worlds. Quite fittingly, Hermione transitioned between the Muggle and wizarding worlds, delivered information, and was pretty sharp-witted herself.
</p>
<figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/8/81/Hermione_Granger_HBPF_promo_5.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20140628045759" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Hermione Granger HBPF promo 5" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="250" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Hermione Granger HBPF promo 5.jpg" data-image-key="Hermione_Granger_HBPF_promo_5.jpg" data-relevant="0" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/8/81/Hermione_Granger_HBPF_promo_5.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20140628045759" /></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/8/81/Hermione_Granger_HBPF_promo_5.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20140628045759" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Hermione Granger HBPF promo 5" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/8/81/Hermione_Granger_HBPF_promo_5.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20140628045759" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="250" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Hermione Granger HBPF promo 5.jpg" data-image-key="Hermione_Granger_HBPF_promo_5.jpg" data-relevant="0" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/harrypotter/images/8/81/Hermione_Granger_HBPF_promo_5.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20140628045759" /></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			<a href="/wiki/File:Hermione_Granger_HBPF_promo_5.jpg" class="info-icon"><svg><use xlink:href="#wds-icons-info-small"></use></svg></a> 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Hermione in her <a href="/wiki/1996" title="1996">sixth year</a></p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermione_(mythology)" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Hermione (mythology)">Hermione</a> is also the name of another figure from Greek mythology, who was the princess of Sparta and the only daughter of Helen of Troy and King Menelaus. The name also appears in Jean-Baptiste Lully's play <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadmus_et_Hermione" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Cadmus et Hermione">Cadmus et Hermione</a></i>, based on the story of the goddess of harmony, Harmonia, who married the founder of Thebes. 
</p><p>In order to ensure that fans could correctly pronounce Hermione's name, a scene was created between Hermione and <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Krum" title="Viktor Krum">Viktor Krum</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire">Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</a></i> in which they discuss the correct pronunciation; however, the closest Krum got was 'Herm-own-ninny'.<sup id="cite_ref-ninny_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ninny-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/The_Last_Will_and_Testament_of_Albus_Percival_Wulfric_Brian_Dumbledore" title="The Last Will and Testament of Albus Percival Wulfric Brian Dumbledore">will</a> of <a href="/wiki/Albus_Dumbledore" title="Albus Dumbledore">Albus Dumbledore</a>, Hermione's middle name was listed as 'Jean'; however, in previous interviews, Rowling had stated that her middle name was 'Jane'. Rowling cleared this up in a later interview by stating that she had decided that she did not want Hermione to share a middle name with <a href="/wiki/Dolores_Umbridge" title="Dolores Umbridge">Professor Umbridge</a>, and thus changed it to Jean, which is a female variant of the name John, meaning 'God is gracious'.<sup id="cite_ref-Jean_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jean-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Granger_(name)" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Granger (name)">Granger</a> is another word for farmer; specifically, it was the title of a farm bailiff, who oversaw the collection of rent and taxes from the barns of a feudal lord. It is a surname of English and French origin, derived from the Anglo-Norman <i>grainger</i> and the French <i>grangier</i>, both of which come from Latin <i>granica</i>, meaning 'granary'. It recalls Hermione's <a href="/wiki/Non-magic_people" title="Non-magic people">Muggle</a> roots. Her original last name was 'Puckle', but Rowling later decided this didn't suit her character.
</p><p>Her initials are the chemical symbol for Mercury, another name for Hermes.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The reason of choosing such an uncommon name as Hermione for the character is because, according to Rowling, she did not bear getting any child mocked because of sharing a name with an 'insufferable know-it-all' such as Hermione.
</p>

<ul><li>Hermione is portrayed by French-born <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">British</a> actress <a href="/wiki/Emma_Watson" title="Emma Watson">Emma Watson</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)" title="Harry Potter (film series)">film adaptations</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)">Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)">Chamber of Secrets</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)">Prisoner of Azkaban</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)">Goblet of Fire</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Order_of_the_Phoenix_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film)">Order of the Phoenix</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Half-Blood_Prince_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)">Half-Blood Prince</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows:_Part_1" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1">Deathly Hallows: Part 1</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows:_Part_2" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2">Part 2</a></i> and is one of the 14 characters to appear in all 8 film adaptations. Watson also portrayed her in the short <i><a href="/wiki/The_Queen%27s_Handbag" title="The Queen's Handbag">The Queen's Handbag</a></i>.</li>
<li>Hermione will be portrayed by Arabella Stanton in the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_(TV_series)" title="Harry Potter (TV series)"><i>Harry Potter</i> television series</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Before Emma Watson was cast, fellow British actress Hatty Jones also auditioned for the role. Jones had risen to fame by playing the titular character in the 1998 live-action film adaptation of the children's book series, Madeline. Of the many girls who auditioned for the Hermione Granger role, only Jones and Watson managed to make the final stage. While the casting agents were impressed and saw potential in both actresses, they deemed Jones a bit outgrown to play the character at the last minute, leading to Watson ultimately being cast.</li>
<li>Emma Watson's body double in the first three films was <a href="/wiki/Flick_Miles" title="Flick Miles">Flick Miles</a>.</li>
<li>Emma Watson's body double in the remaining four films was <a href="/wiki/Ellen_Lister" title="Ellen Lister">Ellen Lister</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Emma Watson actually had to dye her hair darker for the first three films. Emma naturally has light brown hair.
<ul><li>Her hair changes every film, somehow, the cases being:
<ul><li>In the first film, her hair is medium brown, straight, and very bushy.</li>
<li>In the second film, her hair is longer than it ever was in the film series, has grown lighter (caramel brown), and is wavy, not straight.</li>
<li>In <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban"><i>The Prisoner of Azkaban</i></a>, her hair is merely shoulder length and is shown to become curly.</li>
<li>In <i>The Goblet of Fire</i>, her hair has gone a bit bushy again and back to being gently wavy, along with being a lighter brown.</li>
<li>In <i>Order of the Phoenix</i>, Hermione's hair changes yet <i>again</i>: it became almost straight, and its length now reaches just below armpit level.</li>
<li>In <i>The Half-Blood Prince</i>, she is seen with a curlier tone and hair that reaches a few inches above the earlier film.</li>
<li>In the <i>Deathly Hallows</i> films, her hair becomes longer (chest-length) again but reverts to being straight again. Notably, the second film features her hair becoming medium brown again.</li></ul></li></ul></li>
<li>Hermione's hair colour in the last five films became lighter due to Emma Watson reverting to her natural hair colour.</li>
<li>Hermione is portrayed by British actress <a href="/wiki/Noma_Dumezweni" title="Noma Dumezweni">Noma Dumezweni</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Cursed_Child_(play)#West_End" title="Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (play)">original</a> <a href="/wiki/West_End" title="West End">West End</a> <a href="/wiki/Palace_Theatre" title="Palace Theatre">Palace Theatre</a> <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Cursed_Child_(play)#West_End" title="Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (play)">production</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Cursed_Child" title="Harry Potter and the Cursed Child">Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-cast1_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cast1-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sophie_Thompson" title="Sophie Thompson">Sophie Thompson</a> plays Hermione when she is disguised as <a href="/wiki/Mafalda_Hopkirk" title="Mafalda Hopkirk">Mafalda Hopkirk</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows:_Part_1" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1">Deathly Hallows: Part 1</a>, </i>as does <a href="/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter" title="Helena Bonham Carter">Helena Bonham Carter</a> when she is disguised as <a href="/wiki/Bellatrix_Lestrange" title="Bellatrix Lestrange">Bellatrix Lestrange</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows:_Part_2" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2">Deathly Hallows: Part 2</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Radcliffe" title="Daniel Radcliffe">Daniel Radcliffe</a> also plays Hermione in the 'Seven Potters' scene. However, Emma provided the voice for Hermione while she was in disguise on all three occasions.</li>
<li>Although the novels describe Hermione as having rather large front teeth in her younger years, this is not depicted in the films, as Watson never had large teeth and couldn't speak when applied with bucked teeth.</li>
<li>However, in an on-screen commentary for the Blu-Ray release of <i>Philosopher's Stone</i>, reveals that the final scene of the film <i>does</i> show Hermione's large front teeth. According to Columbus, the scene - which was actually the first to be shot - was filmed with Emma Watson wearing fake teeth to simulate the look of Hermione, but that after filming the sequence it was decided to continue using them would have been impractical. Via edits, the appearance of Hermione's teeth is minimised, but they are still visible when she speaks in the scene.</li>
<li>Also, Hermione's hair is only shown as bushy for the first film. Later, her hair is shown as wavy in the second film, and curly in the third film onwards, although it does briefly take on a bushy appearance for comedic effect during the potion-making contest sequence of the film <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Half-Blood_Prince_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)">Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince</a></i>, the film is the second one featuring Hermione with curly hair, after <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a></i>.</li></ul>
<div class="quote">
<dl><dd><span title="Source: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix">"<i>Hermione's Patronus, a shining silver otter, was gambolling around her. 'They are sort of nice, aren't they?' she said, looking at it fondly.</i>"</span></dd>
<dd>— Hermione's Patronus<sup class="noprint"><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Order_of_the_Phoenix" title="Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix">[src]</a></sup></dd>
<dd></dd></dl></div>
<ul><li>Hermione's <a href="/wiki/Patronus_Charm" title="Patronus Charm">Patronus</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Otter" title="Otter">otter</a>, is Rowling's favourite animal. The otter is in the family <i>Mustelidae</i>, the same as the weasel, although the latter do not live near water.</li>
<li>Hermione is rendered Hermelien in Dutch and Hermine in German. They in turn are similar to the words Hermelijn in Dutch and Hermelin in German, which means Stoat, which is a species of Weasel.</li>
<li>In <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</a></i>, Hermione tells <a href="/wiki/Rufus_Scrimgeour" title="Rufus Scrimgeour">Rufus Scrimgeour</a> that she is not planning to pursue career in Magical Law. Ironically, that's where she ends up after leaving Hogwarts, following a stint in the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures.</li>
<li>In the books, Hermione's rivals in the school never appear, but Rowling had plans for a fierce rivalry for Hermione with a student three years her junior - <a href="/wiki/Mafalda" title="Mafalda">Mafalda</a>, a cousin of the Weasley family, who was originally planned to be included in <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire">Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</a></i>, but was ultimately cut. <a href="/wiki/J._K._Rowling" title="J. K. Rowling">J. K. Rowling</a> stated on her website that she was very fond of her, calling her a "match for Hermione", and that she did not want to have to cut her from the book. Her role in the plot would have been to eavesdrop on conversations held between the children of <a href="/wiki/Death_Eaters" title="Death Eaters">Death Eaters</a> in her <a href="/wiki/Slytherin" title="Slytherin">House</a>, then repeat what she heard to the <a href="/wiki/Trio" title="Trio">trio</a> in an attempt to impress them. To Hermione's horror, Mafalda was highly gifted and a real show-off, and Hermione was torn between deploring the rule-breaking and longing to join in and beat her. However, Rowling found that Mafalda "wasn't doing the job she was supposed to do", as there were severe limitations to how much information an eleven-year-old girl stuck at Hogwarts could gather, and consequently developed <a href="/wiki/Rita_Skeeter" title="Rita Skeeter">Rita Skeeter</a> further to fill her role.<sup id="cite_ref-mafalda_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mafalda-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>In early drafts, Hermione was supposed to have a <a href="/wiki/Hermione_Granger%27s_sister" title="Hermione Granger's sister">Muggle sister</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EBF_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EBF-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In a 2004 interview with the BBC on World Book Day, J.K. Rowling revealed the following: 'I always planned that Hermione would have a younger sister but she's never made an appearance and somehow it feels like it might be too late now.' This would have made Hermione very similar to Lily Evans; both muggle-born Witches, both having a Muggle sister, both sorted into Gryffindor, both members of the Order of the Phoenix and both going on to marry pure-blood wizards (Lily marrying pure-blood James Potter and Hermione marrying pure-blood Ron Weasley).</li>
<li>On several occasions - during their frequent bickering - Hermione is seen calling Ron by his full name to express her annoyance. Some examples include her squabble with Ron about <a href="/wiki/Peter_Pettigrew" title="Peter Pettigrew">Scabbers</a> (<i>'Ronald has lost his rat'</i>), and when they argue about Ron's sister <a href="/wiki/Ginevra_Weasley" title="Ginevra Weasley">Ginny</a> dating <a href="/wiki/Dean_Thomas" title="Dean Thomas">Dean Thomas</a> <i>('Honestly Ronald, they're just holding hands - and snogging'</i>).</li>
<li>Hermione admitted to successfully trying out 'a few simple spells' just before her <a href="/wiki/First_year" title="First year">first year</a> at <a href="/wiki/Hogwarts_School_of_Witchcraft_and_Wizardry" title="Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry">Hogwarts</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-PS_3-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PS-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but, in spite of <a href="/wiki/Underage_magic" title="Underage magic">underage magic</a> being banned, she apparently never received a warning from the <a href="/wiki/Improper_Use_of_Magic_Office" title="Improper Use of Magic Office">Improper Use of Magic Office</a> for it. This may be because, since she had not yet attended Hogwarts as an official student, the Ministry overlooked it just as they overlooked when young <a href="/wiki/Tom_Riddle" title="Tom Riddle">Tom Riddle</a> used magic before attending Hogwarts to move objects, help him climb down a steep cliff, etc.; and also as they overlooked when young <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter" title="Harry Potter">Harry</a> made the glass of the boa constrictor cage disappear, made his own hair grow back to normal long length after <a href="/wiki/Petunia_Dursley" title="Petunia Dursley">Aunt Petunia</a> cut it, etc. Severus Snape indicated as much to Lily Evans when they were both children about Lily's own use of magic before she was a student.</li>
<li>The screenwriter for the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)">film adaptation</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Kloves" title="Steve Kloves">Steve Kloves</a> has said that Hermione is his favourite character, commenting: 'There's something about her fierce intellect coupled with a complete lack of understanding of how she affects people sometimes that I just find charming and irresistible to write.'<sup id="cite_ref-DVD_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVD-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>In the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)">film adaptation</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</a></i>, Hermione is shown to be aware of what the term '<a href="/wiki/Mudblood" title="Mudblood">Mudblood</a>' means when <a href="/wiki/Draco_Malfoy" title="Draco Malfoy">Draco Malfoy</a> uses the slur against her, whereas in the novel, she has never heard the word before and Ron explains its meaning to her and Harry.</li>
<li>In <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</a></i>, Professor Binns calls Hermione 'Miss Grant'. It is also made known that Binns calls everyone different names, with Binns also calling Harry Potter 'Mr Perkins'.</li></ul>
<div class="quote">
<dl><dd><span title="Source: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">"<i>Hermione did everything perfectly until she reached the trunk with the Boggart in it. After about a minute inside it, she burst out again, screaming. 'Hermione!' said Lupin, startled. 'What's the matter?' 'P-P-Professor McGonagall!' Hermione gasped, pointing into the trunk. 'Sh-she said I'd failed everything!'</i>"</span></dd>
<dd>— Hermione's Boggart<sup class="noprint"><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">[src]</a></sup></dd>
<dd></dd></dl></div>
<ul><li>Hermione's <a href="/wiki/Boggart" title="Boggart">Boggart</a> in her third year was <a href="/wiki/Minerva_McGonagall" title="Minerva McGonagall">Professor McGonagall</a> telling her that she had 'failed everything', which Rowling later commented showed that "underneath Hermione's snootiness there is a lot of insecurity and a great fear of failure".<sup id="cite_ref-JKRHG_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JKRHG-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>In the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)">film adaptation</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire">Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</a></i>, Hermione is shown to be wearing a pink set of dress robes rather than periwinkle blue, as in the novel.</li>
<li>In the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Half-Blood_Prince_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)">film adaptation</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Half-Blood_Prince" title="Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince">Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince</a></i>, Hermione told <a href="/wiki/Horace_Slughorn" title="Horace Slughorn">Slughorn</a> and the Slug Club about her parents being <a href="/wiki/Dentist" title="Dentist">dentists</a>, but no one, except Harry, knew what dentists were.</li>
<li>Hermione shared a last name with potioneer <a href="/wiki/Hector_Dagworth-Granger" title="Hector Dagworth-Granger">Hector Dagworth-Granger</a>, though she informed <a href="/wiki/Horace_Slughorn" title="Horace Slughorn">Horace Slughorn</a> that she did not think they were related, since she was <a href="/wiki/Muggle-born" title="Muggle-born">Muggle-born</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HBP_36-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HBP-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, the theory that Muggle-borns have some sort of wizarding ancestry suggests Slughorn might be right about Hermione and Hector being related because every Muggle-born must have had a <a href="/wiki/Squib" title="Squib">Squib</a> ancestor.</li>
<li>In <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter" title="Harry Potter">Harry</a> mentions that the only spell Hermione ever had trouble with was the <a href="/wiki/Patronus_Charm" title="Patronus Charm">Patronus Charm</a>, although she was among the first of the D.A. to master the spell and casts it successfully multiple times throughout the series. This may have something to do with the emotional nature of the spell; Harry, due to his inability to cut off his emotions, is particularly adept at this spell, while the logical Hermione has issues with it. It may also have something to do with the caster's self confidence as J.K. Rowling has stated that Hermione is afraid of failure and Harry's first powerful uses of the spell, at a Quidditch match and when he saved Sirius, seem more motivated by his confidence rather then a positive memory.</li>
<li>In <i><a href="/wiki/Harry,_A_History:_The_True_Story_of_a_Boy_Wizard,_His_Fans,_and_Life_Inside_the_Harry_Potter_Phenomenon" title="Harry, A History: The True Story of a Boy Wizard, His Fans, and Life Inside the Harry Potter Phenomenon">Harry, A History</a></i>, Rowling told <a href="/wiki/Melissa_Anelli" title="Melissa Anelli">Melissa Anelli</a> that Steve Kloves had suspected something might happen between Hermione and Harry while reading <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</a></i>: "He felt a certain pull between them at that point. And I think he's right. There are moments when [Harry and Hermione] touch, which are charged moments. One when she touches his hair as he sits on the hilltop reading about Dumbledore and Grindelwald, and [two] the moment when they walk out of the graveyard with their arms around each other. Now the fact is that Hermione shares moments with Harry that Ron will never be able to participate in. He walked out. She shared something very intense with Harry. So I think it could have gone that way."<sup id="cite_ref-HAH_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HAH-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Singer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katy_B" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Katy B">Katy B</a> auditioned to play Hermione but was dismissed when the casting director discovered that she had not read the books.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte_Church" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Charlotte Church">Charlotte Church</a> also auditioned, but was too old for the part.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Watson says that her favourite scene during the film series is the Yule Ball sequence in the fourth film, just like Rupert Grint.</li>
<li>In the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)">film adaptation</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire">Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</a></i>, Hermione snaps at Harry when he tells her to give a message to Ron, saying 'I'm not an owl'. An owl is used for carrying messages, but her name, Hermione, drives from Hermes, the Greek messenger of the gods.</li>
<li>In the same adaptation, the subplot of Hermione standing up for House-Elves rights was left out of the film adaptations entirely.</li>
<li>In <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows:_Part_1" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1</a></i>, Hermione is shown leaving her parents' house, however this is only ever mentioned in the books.
<ul><li>In the same film, Hermione is shown to be able to play the piano, which she attempts to teach <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Weasley" title="Ronald Weasley">Ron</a> to do while at Grimmauld Place.</li>
<li>In the same adaptation, Bellatrix uses her knife to carve the word 'Mudblood' into Hermione's arm during her interrogation. This was not inscribed in the book, but was an idea that Emma Watson came up with, along with Helena Bonham Carter.</li></ul></li>
<li>Hermione cries in seven of the eight films:
<ul><li>First film: After Ron insulted her by saying she has no friends because she is a nightmare, and she hides in the girls' bathroom.</li>
<li>Second film: When she, her friends and the other students cheer for Hagrid after he returns to Hogwarts from Azkaban at the end of the film.</li>
<li>Third film: When she, Harry and Ron saw Buckbeak's apparent execution.</li>
<li>Fourth film: After Ron ruined her night at the Yule Ball.</li>
<li>Sixth film: When Ron started having a relationship with Lavender Brown and when Dumbledore died.</li>
<li>Seventh film: When Ron abandoned her and Harry during the Horcrux hunt, and after Bellatrix has interrogated her and carved the word 'Mudblood' on her arm with <a href="/wiki/Bellatrix_Lestrange%27s_knife" title="Bellatrix Lestrange's knife">her knife</a>.</li>
<li>Eighth film: When she is worried about Harry going into the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_Forest" title="Forbidden Forest">Forbidden Forest</a> to have Voldemort kill him.</li></ul></li>
<li>Hermione's surname was 'Puckle' in early drafts of Harry Potter. It was later changed to Granger.</li>
<li>Initially, J.K. Rowling had stated that Hermione's middle name was 'Jane'. However, Rowling later changed it to 'Jean' after deciding that she did not want Hermione to share a middle name with <a href="/wiki/Dolores_Umbridge" title="Dolores Umbridge">Dolores Umbridge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Jean_82-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jean-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Hermione's <a href="/wiki/Hermione_Granger%27s_wand" title="Hermione Granger's wand">wand</a> <a href="/wiki/Wand_wood" title="Wand wood">wood</a> of vine corresponds to her <a href="/wiki/19_September" title="19 September">birthday</a> in the Celtic calendar, which Rowling did intentionally as a connection between Hermione's wand, <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter%27s_wand" title="Harry Potter's wand">Harry's wand</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Charles_Weasley%27s_wand" title="Charles Weasley's wand">Ron's wand</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the Celtic calendar, the vine was a symbol of passionate emotions in both extremes—happiness and wrath — and was connected to fulfilling goals and finding balance.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>When asked, Rowling said that if Hermione looked into the <a href="/wiki/Mirror_of_Erised" title="Mirror of Erised">Mirror of Erised</a> in the summer of <a href="/wiki/1997" title="1997">1997</a>, she would have seen herself, Harry, and Ron 'alive and unscathed' and <a href="/wiki/Tom_Riddle" title="Tom Riddle">Voldemort</a> defeated, and might also 'see herself closely entwined with <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Weasley" title="Ronald Weasley">a special person</a>'.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Hermione is a playable character in the video game adaptions of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban_(video_game)" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (video game)">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire_(video_game)" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (video game)">Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Half-Blood_Prince_(video_game)" title="Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (video game)">Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince</a></i> (only in duel mode), and <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows:_Part_2_(video_game)" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (video game)">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>In the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban_(video_game)" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (video game)">video game adaptation</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a></i> for PC, Peeves refers to Hermione as 'Grunge'. He always uses the last names for his insulting versions in the games, producing: Potter = Potty, Weasley = Weasel, and Granger = Grunge.</li>
<li>In <i><a href="/wiki/LEGO_Harry_Potter:_Years_1-4" title="LEGO Harry Potter: Years 1-4">LEGO Harry Potter: Years 1-4</a></i>, Hermione has the ability to translate ancient runes from her first year onwards, although she only started studying Study of Ancient Runes in her third year.</li>
<li>A variant of Hermione is available in the 'Downloadable Character Pack' <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downloadable_content" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Downloadable content">DLC</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/LEGO_Harry_Potter:_Years_5-7" title="LEGO Harry Potter: Years 5-7">LEGO Harry Potter: Years 5-7</a></i>. The variant is called 'Hermione (Pink Dress)' because it portrays Hermione wearing the <a href="/wiki/Hermione_Granger%27s_dress_robes" title="Hermione Granger's dress robes">pink dress</a> she wore to the <a href="/wiki/Yule_Ball" title="Yule Ball">Yule Ball</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire_(film)" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)">film adaptation</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire">Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</a></i>.</li>
<li>In the books, several times Ron and Hermione repeat phrases said by one another; for example, when Hermione, in <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone" title="Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone">Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone</a></i>, wanted to produce fire in order to destroy the Devil's Snare, Ron tells her: 'Are you a witch or not?' meaning that they could make fire by their wands. During the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hogwarts" title="Battle of Hogwarts">Battle of Hogwarts</a>, Ron expressed regret for not having Crookshanks there to stop the Whomping Willow and Hermione told him, 'Are you a wizard or not?' leading Ron to levitate a stick into the tree's weak spot. Furthermore, during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Seven_Potters" title="Battle of the Seven Potters">Battle of the Seven Potters</a>, Tonks said Ron was amazing, having defeated many Death Eaters. When Hermione looked surprised, Ron said: 'Always that tone of surprise.' Hermione says the same thing when Ron told her she was very beautiful, during Bill and Fleur's wedding.</li>
<li>Hermione is voiced by American actress <a href="/wiki/Antonia_Vivino" title="Antonia Vivino">Antonia Vivino</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter:_Magic_Awakened" title="Harry Potter: Magic Awakened">Harry Potter: Magic Awakened</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Vivino_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vivino-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Hermione is the only one without any wizarding heritage in the <a href="/wiki/Seven#Out-of-universe" title="Seven">Big Seven</a>.</li></ul>
<h3><span id="Author.27s_comments"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Author's_comments">Author's comments</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/J._K._Rowling" title="J. K. Rowling">J. K. Rowling</a> has claimed that she loosely based Hermione at the age of eleven on herself at the same age, though an exaggerated version:
</p>
<dl><dd>'<i>...none of the characters in the books are directly taken from life. Real people did inspire a few of them, but of course once they are on the page they become something completely different. But, yeah, Hermione is a caricature of what I was when I was eleven — a real exaggeration, I wasn't that clever — Hermione is a borderline genius at points — and I hope I wasn't that annoying... sometimes she is an incredible know-it-all.</i>'<sup id="cite_ref-WBUR_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WBUR-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></dd></dl>
<p>Rowling has gone on to say that Hermione, Harry, and Ron are all '<i>a bit like different parts of my personality</i>' as well as her favourite characters, along with <a href="/wiki/Rubeus_Hagrid" title="Rubeus Hagrid">Rubeus Hagrid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albus_Dumbledore" title="Albus Dumbledore">Albus Dumbledore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fred_Weasley" title="Fred Weasley">Fred</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_Weasley" title="George Weasley">George Weasley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Luna_Lovegood" title="Luna Lovegood">Luna Lovegood</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-EBF_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EBF-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and that Hermione and Dumbledore were the most useful characters for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exposition_(literary_technique)" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Exposition (literary technique)">exposition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DVD_90-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVD-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> She also identified Hermione as 'the most brilliant' of her group of friends and confirmed that '<i>Harry needs her badly</i>.'<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Rowling has also said that she considers Hermione to be '<i>a very strong female character</i>,' as well as '<i>the brightest character</i>.'<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Rowling has also stated that, from a feminist point of view, she is very proud of Hermione. In her words, Hermione does not 'play the game' in refusing to sacrifice parts of herself as she grows from a girl to a woman. Hermione never makes Ron 'feel better' by pretending to be less than she is; she always preserves who she is and waits for Ron to catch up. In general, Rowling regards her as a heroine, but isn't sexy nor entirely sexless, but a 'real girl.'
</p><p>Rowling admitted in an interview conducted by Emma Watson for the magazine <i>Wonderland</i> in February of 2014 that, with hindsight, she initially had some second thoughts on the suitability of Ron as a partner for Hermione and believes that in some ways, Harry might have made a better romantic partner for her:
</p>
<dl><dd><i>'I wrote the Hermione-Ron relationship as a form of wish fulfilment. That's how it was conceived, really. For reasons that have very little to do with literature and far more to do with me clinging to the plot as I first imagined it, Hermione [ended up] with Ron.'</i></dd></dl>
<p>She went on to say that she found the attraction itself plausible, but that the combative side of it might cause problems in an adult relationship as there was too much fundamental incompatibility. However, according to Rowling, they could 'probably be alright' with a bit of marriage counselling, as Ron needed to work on his self-esteem issues while Hermione needed to learn to be less critical. She concluded with the statement that just like herself, the uptight Hermione had a real weakness for a funny man. Ultimately, Rowling stated she had no regrets putting them together and stated the two balanced each other out and truly love one another.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Appearances">Appearances</span></h2>

<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone" title="Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone">Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone</a></i> <small>(First appearance)</small></li>

<li><i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a></i></li>
